a_text: Yes, this is not the only way to determine a "good ear for music", so therefore you can set up a hypothesis and test specific to this to obtain statistics that could apply inference to a greater or entire population of music listeners.

Collect 10 TVs from the bulk order and inspect them to determine if the display screens are bad then use a 1 proportion z interval to make a 95% confidence interval for this sample. If the confidence interval is below 5% than accept the order. If the confidence interval is above or includes 5% than they should reject the order.

Statistical inference should not be used to determine whether Carla has a "good ear for music" because that statement is ambiguous. Different people could interpret that statement many different ways and would therefore skew the accuracy of this. In order to use statistical inference one would have to clearly define what a "good ear for music" was.

Because there is only one set answer and set of data for this problem, statisitical inference may not be appropriate to use. The person being tested can either get the note right or wrong, and there is no population to determine and compare to. The way to go about this is using the random association with the note playing as the problem suggests. If Carla gets more than half wrong, she most likely does not have a "good ear for music," but if Carla were to guess more than half correctly and then given the test a second time and guessed less than half, would she then be considered not having a good ear for music, or does this type of test have too much bias and support for their answer?

You should not use statistic inference in this scenario because the frequency of correct responses will be different for each person based on genetic predisposition to pitch sensitivity. The definition of "good ear for music" is not clearly defined enough to show if her natural ability makes her more suseptible to accel in this area of testing. There is not a control to measure against in this experiment. A better alternative would be to measure Carla's progress over time in doing this experiment or compare her results with that of other students.

Statistical inference should not be used to determine whether Mark or Dan is a better Walleye fisherman because the difference in fish length caught is due to other factors which most likely caused them to catch more or less large fish. It may be better for the fishermen to take a test comparing fishing knowledge rather than using statistical inference.

I don't believe that statistical inference would be a good way of determining if Carla has a good ear for music. You could give the number of notes she got correct, but you would have no parameter to compare her with. You could, however, make a histogram of her classmates and Carla's scores.

The statistical inference should not be used to determine who is a better walleye fisherman, because statistical inference is used mainly to draw conclusions about a population.  In this scenario, we are comparing the average lengths of walleye that Dan and Mark caught; we are not trying to determine the average length of the walleye population in that area.

I would conduct a hypothesis test to determine whether to accept or reject the shipment of display screens. /  / 1.  I would take a random sample from the 150 display screens (following the 10% rule, I would take no more than 15 display screens from the population.  Let's take only 10, which would be 6.7%).  I would then test the sample to find the proportion of bad display screens.  For my hypothesis test, I would use an alpha-score of 0.05. /  / 2.  Before I continued on with the hypothesis test, I would double check the Success/Failure condition. /      n(p)=150(0.067)=10.05 /      n(1-p)=150(0.933)=148.95 /      Both of these values are greater than 10, so the Success/Failure condition is met. /  / 3.  I would determine my null and alternative hypothesis. /      Null hypothesis: p=0.05 /      Alternative hypothesis: p>0.05 /  / 4.  I would then find the sampling distribution of p-hat if the null hypothesis is true.  P-hat would be normally distributed if all the conditions are met.  I would then use the mean (p-nought=0.05) to find the standard deviation (the square root of p(1-p)/n). /  / 5.  Once I have found the standard deviation, I can use that to determine the test statistic.  I can calculate the z-score by subtracting the p-hat from the p-nought, and then dividing that by the standard deviation.   /  / 6.  As soon as I have the z-score, I can go to the normal (or z) table and determine the p-value.  Once I have the P-value, I can then see how it compares to the alpha-score (0.05).   /      If the P-value is less than the alpha-score, I can reject the null hypothesis. /      If the P-value is greater than the alpha-score, I do not have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis; I fail to reject it. /  / 7.  After determining whether or not to reject the null hypothesis, I would be able to conclude if more than 5% of the display screens are bad for the entire population of 150 display screens.  I would then be able to decide to reject or accept the shipment. /
